Award.AwardTitle: The Relationship between Natural Environments, Fatigue, and Attention

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The United Nations estimates that by the year 2050 roughly 70% of the world's population will be living in highly urbanized areas. This increase in urban living comes with many benefits: sustainable spaces for living, increased flow of ideas and innovation, better proximity to services, and diverse communities. Unfortunately, urban life as it stands is also associated with increased stress, worse physical and mental health, and shorter life expectancy. All of these negative effects alter our physiology, brain, and behavior. By understanding the psychological, neural, and physiological mechanisms underlying the relationship between exposure to nature and cognitive performance, future studies will be able to more easily implement interventions aimed at improving built spaces in order to enhance the potential for human productivity and vitality. This research is guided by Attention Restoration Theory, which posits that incorporating natural elements into the built environment can counteract some of the negatives of urban life. Results from this proposal could be used to help design schools, offices, homes, cities and towns to optimize human functioning.

Philosophers, writers, and lay people have had the intuition for centuries that interacting with nature has myriad benefits to human functioning. While this intuition is appealing, it needs rigorous testing. This project aims to identify the mechanisms through which interactions with natural environments might enhance both behavior and brain function, using cutting edge neuroscience, psychophysiological and machine-learning tools. The primary objectives of this research project are the following. First the research will examine the psychological, physiological, and neural processes that are altered during interactions with natural environments. It will address questions such as how hard must the brain work when processing more natural vs. more urban stimuli, and how does this processing affect people's ability to focus. Second, the research will determine some of the characteristics (e.g., low-level visual features such as color, edge content, fractalness, etc.) of natural and urban environments that lead to psychological improvements or decrements. This information will aid understanding of some of the visual features that may be producing these benefits, which could then be used to help design new built spaces or retrofit existing built spaces. Third, the research will test whether individuals who are in more mentally fatigued states will benefit more from natural vs. urban environment exposure. This aspect of the work will help to define the neural and psychophysiological basis of mental fatigue. In summary, this research project aims to understand how interactions with different environments affect human functioning, and what interventions can be made to improve human functioning at large scales.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proposed project aimed to identify the mechanisms through which interactions with natural environments might enhance both behavior and brain function, with a particular emphasis on the potential role of fatigue in mediating such results. The primary objectives of this proposal were to: 1) Examine the psychological, physiological, and neural processes that are altered during interactions with natural environments; 2) determine if the nature effects are enhancing and/or if the contrasting urban environments are fatiguing or both; 3) quantify hard vs. soft fascination and their relevance to fatigue; and 4) determine the design elements (e.g., low-level visual features) of natural and urban environments that lead to psychological improvements or decrements.

Intellectual Merit: First, this proposal tests a theoretical framework for the types of environments that lead to positive psychological and physiological outcomes. Second, this proposal attempts to enumerate the low-level visual features (e.g., curved edges and fractalness) that may be contributing to these benefits and, in particular, whether there are stimuli that can softly capture attentional resources that lead to positive benefits. Third, this proposal examines how background processing of the physical environment can be fatiguing and helps to define what this fatigue looks like. These three features would help to shape future cognitive theories related to attention, fatigue, and environmental influences on behavior.

Broader Impacts: Results of this proposal could pave the way for the design of restorative interventions that leverage aspects of the natural environment. These interventions could benefit a broad and diverse population base, from disadvantaged inner city neighborhoods, to wealthy towns, from school environments to high-rise corporate offices. Recent research has shown that natural spaces in urban environments have significant health benefits (Kardan et al., 2015c; Mitchell & Popham, 2008), improve school performance (Dadvand et al., 2015), and reduce crime (Kuo & Sullivan, 2001a, 2001b), all of which benefit society more broadly. This work has implications for the design of built environments, including but not limited to schools, cities, towns, hospitals, prisons, and work places. As a whole, individuals and researchers tend to ignore the impact of the physical environment on cognitive functioning, but doing so may come at a price. By deepening our understanding of how the physical environment affects cognition and health, we can improve the design of our environments and daily life activities. This, in turn, could lead to improvements in human productivity and well-being at a relatively low-cost.

Project Outcomes: Significant results/outcomes from this proposal are the following. First, we determined that perceiving higher quantities of curved edges, causes participants to think more reflectively and positively (Schertz & Berman, 2019; Schertz et al., 2018; Schertz et al., 2019a). Second, we found replicable results of short-exposures to natural environments (sounds, pictures and movies) to increase a varied amount of cognitive functions (Stenfors et al., 2019; Van Hedger et al., 2018; Bourrier et al., 2019). Third, we determined that the benefits of nature are due to nature improving performance, but also certain urban environments worsening performance (Bourrier et al., 2019).  Fourth, we found that when individuals interact with greenspace more often, via park visits, there are associated reductions in crime in their home neighborhoods, controlling for age, education, income, ethnicity and other demographic factors (Schertz et al., 2019b). Fifth, we validated a measure of cognitive effort/fatigue using a non-linear dynamics measure with EEG (Kardan et al., 2019) that can be used to quantify effort of processing environmental stimulation (such as natural vs. urban environments). Sixth we found that architectural scenes, that mimic the patterns of nature (such as fractalness) are more preferred, are rated as more comforting and are rated as being more natural, even though they contain no overt natural content (Coburn et al., 2018).  Seventh, we built a web-based application, ReTUNE, that can route individuals from any two walkable points in Chicago to maximize greenspace, minimize sound, and minimize crime.  This app can help to improve human well-being in urban areas.
